author: Keir Mudie
title: Scrapping child burial fees to end heartbreak for grieving families agreed by another council
text:
News Scrapping child burial fees to end heartbreak for grieving families agreed by another council Oxford votes unanimously to remove the charges for grieving parents, as pressure grows on the Government to scrap them for good Share Child burial fees add more stress for grieving parents (Photo: Getty) Share Get politics   Thank you for subscribing! Could   
Another council has backed the Sunday Mirror’s campaign to scrap child burial fees and end heartbreak for grieving parents. 
Since we launched our campaign - along with Labour - last year, a number of councils have agreed to cancel their child burial fees. 
Now Oxford councillors have voted unanimously to get rid of the charges for youngsters. 
At a meeting this week Cllr Ruth Wilkinson said: “The loss of a loved one is always very sad, but the loss of a much longed-for-baby or infant must be almost unbearable. 
“It is hard for us to comprehend how difficult it must be for grieving families to cope with this tragic circumstance at what should be a very happy time.” Read More Council urges local authorities to follow them in doing "right thing" by scrapping child burial charges Oxford councillors voted unanimously to remove the charges (Photo: Getty) 
Oxford council made just £5,100 from child burials last year and Mrs Wilking said it made sense to scrap the fees. 
During the emotional meeting, fellow councillor Mark Lygo revealed he had lost a child in 1999. 
He said: “My wife was nearly full term, just over eight months and it was very traumatic and stressful at the time. 
“And one of the stresses for us was trying to find the money. 
We are calling for an end to funeral costs for the 5,000 people who lose a child every year. Read More Child burial fees closer to being scrapped so heartbroken families don't have to pay thousands Child burials would cost the Government £10m a year if charges were scrapped (Photo: Getty) 
Along with Labour, we want the government to cover the estimated £10m it costs for burials. At the moment, individual councils set the rate and it is up to them whether they charge or waive the fee. 
MP Carolyn Harris - who lost her son Martin in a car accident in 1989 - has been leading the fight. 
She was forced to take out a loan to bury the eight-year-old. 
She said: “I’m extremely touched by the compassion shown by Oxford councillors. They join local authorities all over the UK who are doing the right thing. 
“On March 8 the government has a chance to put a Children’s Funeral Fund in the Budget and help ease the pain of grieving families.” Like us on Facebook
